data.title: Incorrect doc-block autocomplete
data.body:
Atom 0.199.0/win32 with all community packages disabled incorrectly autocompletes the following as soon as @ is typed:

``` javascript
/**
 * @
```

This gets completed to...

``` javascript
/**
 /**
  * @
```
- only happens on the first line after a `/*` or `/**`
- happens regardless of document type (tested js, plain text and markdown)
- if there is a line right below the @, cursor will be moved to the end of that line, otherwise will behind the @
- tried  `'ctrl-alt-q': 'unset!'` under `'.platform-win32 .editor'` in keymap.cson to no effect (suggested here: https://github.com/atom/atom-keymap/issues/35)

Sorry if this is a duplicate. Is there a way to search for single, non-alphanumeric characters on github (i.e. @) ?

data.title: An error message shows up with no obvious abnormal behavior
data.body:
The following message keeps on appearing on the top right corner of atom when I am leaving my settings page. I don't sense any abnormal behavior but I guess it may be related to something at the background and you may want to know, so I copy the message using the default copy function and paste it below.

[Enter steps to reproduce below:]
1. ...
2. ...

**Atom Version**: 0.199.0
**System**: Microsoft Windows 7 Home Premium N 
**Thrown From**: [highlight-selected](https://github.com/richrace/highlight-selected) package, v0.9.3
### Stack Trace

Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'dispose' of undefined


data.title: Editor freeze on opening html file
data.body:
Lenovo G550. 4gb ram. Intel graphics.
Atom 0.999.
Opening small html 41kb. On opening html editor freeze for for few minutes and showing one popup()
![error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6039696/7669052/b1b4188c-fc7b-11e4-88e6-cf2e8f156344.png)

data.title: shell command `atom` not opening the current directory
data.body:
Normally when I type `atom` in an OSX terminal, Atom opens the current directory with tree view enabled. However, when I upgraded to 0.199.0, it just opens up a blank project with `untitled` tab.

I've tried `Install shell commands` menu under `Atom` tab with no success. Anyone else experiencing this?

Using OSX Yosemite 10.10.3. Happening on both Terminal 2.5.3 (343.7), and iTerm2 Build 2.1.1.

data.title: Annoying behavior: Atom steals window focus during startup
data.body:
Here's a GIF: http://g.recordit.co/XVdFRbpFRV.gif

After launching Atom from terminal, I clicked on the terminal window to maintain focus, but while Atom was starting, it stole focus (as in the current active window) many times.

It's specially annoying since Atom is slow and I want to use the time it takes to be ready in other activities.

Atom is `0.199.0` on OS X Yosemite.

data.title: Unable to re-install disabled packages
data.body:
How to reproduce:
- Go to settings -> Install
- Find a package you have installed at the moment
- Press disable and after that click on uninstall
- Restart atom
- Search for your disabled/uninstalled package

You will now see that it is uninstalled AND disabled, but it can't be enabled anymore.
To circumvent this bug you have to use apm through the console in order to re-install that package.

Atom version: ~~0.119.0~~ 0.199.0
OS: Windows 8.1 Pro 64 bit

data.title: atom command line doesn't launch the current folder without arguments
data.body: Pre **v0.199.0** just typing `atom` from the terminal would open the current working directory. It was the equivalent of `atom .` but now it just launches the app with no directory. Is this change intentional or is it a bug?

data.title: Doesn't Scope Whitespace Between Words
data.body:
That means that show invisibles won't show spaces in lines of text.

See also https://github.com/atom/whitespace/issues/50

data.title: Include atom-tree-view-breadcrumb in core?
data.body: I was browsing Atom's available packages and I discovered [this](https://github.com/abe33/atom-tree-view-breadcrumb) one. It's not adding (almost) any performance penalties and improves greatly the usability of the tree sidebar with big sub-folders structures, so I thought maybe it could get included in Atom's default packages?

data.title: Would it be possible to install under %UserProfile%\AppData instead of directly under %UserProfile% on Windows?

data.title: Create a viewer API
data.body:
We already have Markdown and ASCIIDoc files that have their respective viewers for the rendered version of the document. We have viewers for images and there is a package for "viewing" audio files. And then I saw the [perldoc package](https://atom.io/packages/perldoc) today, which extracts the documentation from the current file, renders it and views it.

We should have one API with, most importantly, **one** keybinding to be used to view or preview _any_ file type. So no matter what the active file is, if I hit <kbd>Ctrl+Alt+P</kbd> (for example) the registered viewer for that file type opens up in a new pane. If more than one viewer for that file type is registered, you can select the default one ... or press, for example, <kbd>Shift+Ctrl+Alt+P</kbd> to bring up a viewer list and select one.
## Requirements

> The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED",  "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in [RFC 2119](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2119.txt).
- **MUST** allow packages to register viewers by scope name using the services API
- **MUST** offer a command `file-viewer:open` to open the single (or default) registered viewer for the file in the active editor (or selected file in the tree-view)
- **MUST** offer a command `file-viewer:listViewers` to open the list of registered viewers for the file in the active editor (or selected file in the tree-view)
- **SHOULD** allow the single (or default) registered viewer to be opened for files that do not have an "opener" registered, such as image, archive or audio types
- **OPTIONAL** offer a hex viewer as an option for all file types (see the [hex package](https://atom.io/packages/hex) for an awesome example)
## Questions
- When preview tabs are enabled, how should viewer tabs behave?
  - Should they be preview tabs? Only sticking around permanently if the tab title is double-clicked?
  - Should they be permanent tabs?
  - Should they be preview tabs, but of their own class so only other preview tabs override them?

data.title: If all windows are closed preferences does not open
data.body:
under OSX 10.10.3 atom build 0.199.0 if you close all windows then hit atom->preferences the preferences windows does not come up. You have to do it twice.

If using keyboard shortcuts you must hit command+, two times in order to actually get the presences window.

Expected behavior: hit it once and the preferences window comes up. If no windows are currently open then it should not only open a window, but then automatically open preferences.

data.title: Unable to auto-update from 0.198.0 to 0.199.0 on Windows
data.body:
Refs: https://discuss.atom.io/t/unable-to-auto-update-from-0-181-0/16896/

I was initially having issues upgrading from Atom 0.181.0 to the new 0.199.0, but then I updated manually to 0.198.0 and still had the problem trying to update to 0.199.0.  I cleared out the Squirrel log from all the old tries, cleared out the package cache, and got the following error:

```
UpdateInfo: Couldn't get release notes for:atom-0.199.0-full.nupkg: System.Exception: Invalid 'ReleaseNotes' value in nuspec file at 'C:\Users\moshe\AppData\Local\atom\..\atom\packages\atom-0.199.0-full.nupkg'
   at Squirrel.ReleaseEntry.GetReleaseNotes(String packageDirectory)
   at Squirrel.UpdateInfo.<FetchReleaseNotes>b__2(ReleaseEntry x)
```

What's wrong here?

Was the `nupkg` file just generated wrong?

data.title: EISDIR: illegal operation on a [particular] directory
data.body:
While attempting to open a folder, I got the error below. After renaming, it opened just fine. Making a new, empty folder with the same name yielded the same error.

I'm on OS X 10.10.4 using 0.199.0. The path is still read- and usable to other processes, and just before manually installing 0.199.0, I had the folder open and working fine with 0.194.0.

Rebooting didn't help, so I'll look for references to the path in Atom's config files and on my system.

```
index.js:62 Error: EISDIR: illegal operation on a directory, read
    at Error (native)
    at Object.fs.readSync (fs.js:596:19)
    at Object.fs.readFileSync (fs.js:428:28)
    at Object.fs.readFileSync (ATOM_SHELL_ASAR.js:369:29)
    at File.module.exports.File.readSync (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/pathwatcher/lib/file.js:248:36)
    at TextBuffer.module.exports.TextBuffer.updateCachedDiskContentsSync (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/text-buffer.js:940:85)
    at TextBuffer.module.exports.TextBuffer.loadSync (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/text-buffer.js:969:12)
    at Project.module.exports.Project.buildBufferSync (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/project.js:431:14)
    at Project.module.exports.Project.bufferForPathSync (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/project.js:407:61)
    at TokenizedBuffer.module.exports.TokenizedBuffer.deserializeParams (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/tokenized-buffer.js:82:36)index.js:62 handleSetupError
```

data.title: Initial paths shouldn't be normalized on save and restore (could contain uris)
data.body:
Including url-style paths like `remote://host:port/some/path` in the `initialPaths` causes state loss issues, because the hash creation in: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/atom.coffee#L93 creates a key that's different from the key got when restoring the state, because the `initialPaths` are normalized and not existing (see: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/browser/atom-application.coffee#L372).

So, when the initialPaths contain a url, the state is never restored

This diff makes sure that project paths and `initialPaths` aren't normalized when not local paths

@bolinfest @maxbrunsfeld @benogle

data.title: `cmd + shift + click` to add mutliple extra cursors in one go
data.body:
`cmd + click` adds an extra cursor in the editor.

`cmd + shift + click` currently behaves in a weird way that does not appear to be intended. My expectation was for `cmd + shift + click` to add multiple cursors on the lines between the last added cursor and the click position (on the same column as the click).

Does this sound like a good idea? I know I would find it rather useful.

data.title: :arrow_up: markdown-preview@0.149.0
Atom as a Chrome OS App
data.body:
Atom is mostly all written in coffee, and Google Chrome Apps are JS based(would have to package all assets and resources for the app). 

Would it be possible to turn Atom into a Google Chrome App? 

I am thinking if I should invest time to to making it happen, because I recently bought a Chrome Book and would really like to have Atom as a Google App.

data.title: Change hard coded restrictions to enable more correct indentions
data.body:
Currently the hard coded restrictions prevent some very valid use cases (will add a before and after screencasts at the bottom) and limit the possibilities to implement correct indentation.

Before:
![before](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4171547/7628544/db28e958-fa24-11e4-9599-126bd61ef749.gif)
As you can see here the bracket isn't indented correctly when moving it to the next line. The decreaseIndentPattern is correct as it does increase when removing and typing in the bracket again on the same line.

After:
![after](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4171547/7628620/df8dfb5e-fa25-11e4-9056-b58b4aee31fa.gif)
After removing the hard coded restrictions, the bracket is indented as expected.

data.title: Atom v0.199.0 Closes when pressing any menu Option
data.body: After upgrading to version v0.199.0 Atom closes on OS X Yosemite when pressing any menu option like `atom, file, edit` etc.

data.title: Avatars in package view sometimes do not render
data.body:
In console there's this line:

> Resource interpreted as Image but transferred with MIME type text/plain: "file:///C:/[snip]/Atom/Cache/settings-view/atom-1431701305839".

And looking up that file shows that's its a empty 0kb file.

Perhaps it should check if the cached file can actually be used before using it, and why did it cache an empty file in first place.
